Now what about recession, the R-word?
Do you think that we are headed for it or are other factors going to compensate for things like the real-estate market?
I think that we are going to have a very middling economy.
I'm reluctant to say recession.
These kinds of predictions tend to be self-fulfilling.
But certainly about a third of the members of the Association of Business Economists are saying that they think recession is coming.

A couple of reasons, the whole issue of what is happening with interest rates; certainly the issue of energy prices; Iraq, of the spending that we're spending in Iraq, really is dragging from the spending we can do domestically.
And that has an impact as well.
So there is a certain possibility that that may happen.
We also could see a better job situation.
In November, we only expanded by 130,000 jobs.
Really, if we want to see robust growth, we need to see 250,000 jobs being created every month.
And so the question will be, can we do better in 2007?

Now when we talk about jobs, you mentioned a certain number of jobs that have to be created to really keep the economy afloat, but one thing that I've been fascinated by is that the unemployment rate that is stated by the government may not reflect all the people who are actually without jobs.
Explain how the unemployment rate and discouraged workers work, and how that affects the black community in particular?
The unemployment rate measures the people who are either physically working or looking for work.
If you haven't had a job in a year but you tell the census person you wish you had one, you're not counted as unemployed.
You're a discouraged worker.
You're not in the statistic at all.
So what you see with African-American men in particular are employment population ratios that are low.
Now the employment population ratio, as opposed to the unemployment rate, just tells you the percentage of people who are working.
So of a hundred black men in the universe - in New York City, only 50 of that 100 are working - 50 or not in the age of 16 to 65.
That's absurd.
Overall, for African-American men, the numbers is closer to 60, but it's still much lower than it is for men of other races.
For African-American women it's lower than for white women, but it's higher than it is for black men.
But the bottom line here is we're not measuring every single able-bodied person who could work.
We're only measuring those who are looking for work.
Here's where the discouraged-worker phenomenon comes in.
There are no jobs in your neighborhood.
You have looked everywhere.
You've knocked on every door.
There's no transportation.
And so, at some point, you say forget it.
I've been doing this for a year.
I'm not going to do it anymore.
Soon as you do that, you're not counted anymore.

So while people can talk about great spending programs and cutting taxation, the bottom line is we have expenditures that can cripple us in the long run if we don't deal with them.

And, Mr. Berman, for those who believe that lobbying in general has a certain odor to it, how do you defend what you do?
I defend it because I'm just comfortable with it.
I mean, I think I'm a pretty ethical person.
There's been lobbying--if you think about the people that have lobbied this Congress over the years, it's always been part of the system.
You know, FBI agents lobbying the White House because they didn't like pardons that were going to be given.
I remember a young man that I met in the District of Columbia who, at the age of 13, began, quote, unquote, ""lobbying"" full time to get statehood for the District of Columbia.
And he by himself went from--obviously he wasn't successful--went from office to office and always got heard out because when this 13-year-old showed up, people were--found it interesting.

In a time of climate change denial and vaccine resistance, scientists worry they are losing the public trust.
But a new survey finds just the opposite.
Public trust of scientists is growing.
It's on par with trust of the military and far above trust of clergy, politicians and journalists.
NPR's Richard Harris reports.
The survey by the Pew Research Center finds 86% of those surveyed said they have a fair amount or a great deal of faith that scientists act in our best interests.
And that's been trending higher.
But Cary Funk, director of science and society research at the Pew Research Center says the picture isn't entirely rosy.
It tends to be kind of a soft support.
The public doesn't entirely trust scientists to do their jobs well or to act in the public interest, she found.
When you look at issues of scientific integrity, we see widespread skepticism.
